p.s: Like all ShakespearanShakespearean sonnets, number 60 consists of 14 verses, so that there are four stanzas, namely three quatrains and at the end, one couplet.
The rhyme scheme in the quatrains is always the crossed rhyme abab cdcd efef and in the couplet, it is the pair rhyme gg.
The metre is an iambic pentametre.
All sonnets of Shakespeare are structured in the same maniermanner, so that a big worth of recognizing comes into being.
The permanant metre creates a flow that makes the poem very succinct.
The first quatrain leads into the topic.
The reader gets straight into it because of the simile like as the waves (l. 1).
Words from the worldfieldword field sea like waves (l. 1) and pebbled shore (l. 1) get used to symbolize freedom.
The second line is full of words about time like minutes (l. 2) and end (l. 2) to show that time is an important factor of life, too.
For this reason, the third and fourth line indicate that everything passes by using examples like [e]ach changing place (l. 3).
The second quatrain portrays the topic with help of images.
The metaphors main of light (l. 5) and crawls to maturity (l. 6) explain that the centre of life is to become an adult.
The crooked eclipses (l. 7) are a symbol for the negative sides of life to show that the time is a possibility or rather gift (l. 8) to explore how life works.
To show his own opinion, Shakespeare uses the third quatrain.
He explains that there is enough time in the youth to create yourself by using the metaphor Time doth transfix the flurish set on youth (l. 9).
To stay in contact with the second quatrain, he repeats the word time (l. 8, l. 9).
Following, he comes to the topic love in connection to the youth by talking about beauty's brow (l. 10).
Here, the metaphor Feeds on the rarities of nature's truth helps Shakespeare to express that love needs to be cared.
That the death is never far away, is shown by the metaphor And nothing stands but for his scythe to mow (l. 12).
The couplet expresses Shakespeare's wish that his words get the recognition they deserve.
The symbol cruel hand (l. 14) at the end asks the readers to remind that the death can be everywhere, so that they should use their time.
Probably, the lyrical I, that speaks to us, is Shakespeare self.
His poems are namely very private and he probably never wanted them to be published.

Although there are theories that Shakespeare never existed, whoever wrote his poems, was very smart, because he invented more than 1500 new words and expressed better than everyone else what it is like to be a human being.
His addresseeaddressees are all human, especially the younger ones, because he gives a general advise for life.
All in all, Shakespeare wantwants to teach people that they have to love their life.
So, my assumption from the beginning is right.
Shakespeare is an artist, whose words are so powerful that he can bring an important message in only 14 strong verses to millions of people.
